data.title: Cheniere expects to export 50M metric tons of LNG for first time in 2026, CEO says
data.description:
Cheniere Energy (LNG) expects to export more than 50 million metric tons of liquefied natural gas for the first time next year, CEO Jack Fusco said Thursday.

The increase is being driven by the projected completion of an expansion at Cheniere's (LNG) Corpus Christi facility in Louisiana that will add 10 million metric tons/year of capacity, Fusco said on the company's earnings conference call, according to Reuters.

Talks between President Trump and China's President Xi as well as several other Asian leaders have provided more optimism about increased LNG exports to the region, Fusco also said.

Cheniere (LNG) still plans for further expansion but only if future projects meet clear criteria, CFO Zach Davis said on the call; specifically, 95% of any new facility's capacity must be sold on long-term contracts, Cheniere must fund 50% of the project, and return on investment needs to be based on lower margins and must be at least 10%.

Some other LNG developers had been undisciplined in greenlighting new projects, as some "projects are getting over the FID finish line with a very broad array of counterparties and at times no counterparties," Chief Commercial Officer Anatol Feygin said.

LNG prices likely will start dropping next year, with an additional 30 million-40 million metric tons/year of LNG expected to come on the market through 2030, Feygin also said, although Cheniere's (LNG) long-term contracting and efficiency will provide some protection from falling LNG prices.

Cheniere (LNG) closed +0.2% on Thursday after reporting Q3 net income climbed to $1.05 billion, or $4.75/share, from $893 million, or $3.93/share, in the year-earlier quarter, and revenues rose 18% Y/Y to $4.44 billion.

data.title: Encompass Health outlines 127+ annual bed additions through 2027 as demand accelerates
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Encompass Health Corporation (EHC) Q3 2025

Management View

  • CEO Mark Tarr highlighted a strong quarter: "Revenue in Q3 increased 9.4% and adjusted EBITDA grew 11.4%, contributing to year-to-date revenue growth of 10.6% and adjusted EBITDA growth of 14.5%. Owing largely to our Q3 results, we have again increased our 2025 guidance."
  • Tarr emphasized quality metrics, noting a Q3 discharge community rate of 84.6%, discharge to acute rate of 8.6%, and discharge to SNF rate of 6%, all exceeding industry averages. He stated, "Our high-quality patient care was again recognized by Newsweek and Statista who named Encompass Health America's most awarded leader in inpatient rehabilitation for the sixth consecutive year."
  • Strategic expansion included the opening of three new hospitals in Q3 (Danbury, CT; Daytona Beach, FL; Wildwood, FL) and 39 additional beds to existing hospitals. Tarr added, "We expect to open 2 additional 50-bed hospitals in Q4...and add approximately 37 beds to existing hospitals."
  • Expansion plans have increased, with Tarr stating, "We now expect to add approximately 127 beds to existing hospitals in 2025 and approximately 150 to 200 in both 2026 and 2027. Our pipeline...currently consists of 14 hospitals with 690 beds."
  • The company converted its ERP system to Oracle Fusion in October, with Tarr reporting, "We experienced no significant disruptions to our operations from the conversion."
  • CFO Douglas Coltharp commented, "Revenue growth of 9.4% in Q3 was driven primarily by a 5% increase in total discharges and a 3.3% increase in net revenue per discharge."

Outlook

  • Coltharp reported, "We have again raised our 2025 guidance. We now assume net operating revenue of $5.905 billion to $5.955 billion, adjusted EBITDA of $1.235 billion to $1.255 billion and adjusted earnings per share of $5.22 to $5.37."
  • The company now projects annual bed additions to existing hospitals of about 127 in 2025 and 150 to 200 in both 2026 and 2027, increases compared to prior projections.

Financial Results

  • Adjusted EBITDA increased 11.4% to $300.1 million in Q3 2025.
  • Q3 included $10.8 million in net provider tax revenue, a $7.7 million increase from Q3 2024, with retroactive payments from Tennessee and West Virginia.
  • Adjusted free cash flow for Q3 was $174.2 million, down 8.2% due to a $55.8 million increase in working capital related to the ERP transition. Year-to-date free cash flow increased 16.5% to $582.5 million. Full-year adjusted free cash flow guidance was raised to $730 million to $810 million.
  • During Q3, the company repurchased 221,000 shares for $25 million, bringing the year-to-date total to $82 million.
  • Net leverage at quarter end was 2x; the company retired the remaining $100 million balance of its 2025 senior notes.

Q&A

  • Joanna Gajuk, BofA Securities: Asked about the impact of accelerated bed addition plans on future volume growth and the long-term growth algorithm. Coltharp responded that increasing bed expansions validates the business model, stating, "Bed additions to existing hospitals offer the highest return on invested capital we have."
  • Pito Chickering, Deutsche Bank: Asked about CapEx as a percent of revenue and occupancy targets. Coltharp explained growth CapEx at the midpoint estimate is about $580 million and discussed bed expansion triggers when occupancy crosses 80%.
  • Ann Hynes, Mizuho Securities: Inquired about surprises in the quarter and Washington outlook. Coltharp cited retroactive provider tax payments and a property assessment as timing-related, but otherwise noted performance was "pretty much in line with our expectations."
  • Matthew Gillmor, KeyBanc: Asked about payer mix. Coltharp noted balanced growth across payers, with managed care up 9.2% and the VA Community Care network up nearly 26%.
  • Benjamin Mayo, Leerink Partners: Asked about volume fluctuations and regulatory programs. Coltharp stated, "Volume in the quarter was kind of a U-shape...we didn't see anything looking at the third quarter results that said we need to make a course correction."
  • Andrew Mok, Barclays: Asked about hospital consolidations and Medicare landscape. COO Patrick Tuer said closures were unique events; Coltharp noted flexibility in payer mix planning.
  • Albert Rice, UBS: Asked about development pipeline and competition. Coltharp detailed 14 announced projects and a 40-project active pipeline, highlighting high barriers to entry.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts focused on occupancy, capacity expansion, payer mix, and labor trends, with questions aimed at clarifying growth sustainability and operational headwinds. The tone was neutral to slightly positive, probing for more detail on volume fluctuations and guidance rationale.
  • Management maintained a confident and positive tone in prepared remarks, emphasizing growth, operational execution, and market opportunity. In Q&A, responses remained measured and constructive, with Coltharp frequently reiterating, "We continue to be very optimistic about the market that is in front of us."
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management's confidence appeared consistent, but analyst tone was somewhat more focused on potential headwinds and clarification of growth levers.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance for revenue, adjusted EBITDA, and EPS was raised again, reflecting continued confidence versus the previous quarter.
  • Expansion targets increased: projected bed additions for 2025 rose from approximately 110 to 127, with 2026 and 2027 now projected at 150 to 200 each year, compared to 120 previously.
  • Analysts' focus shifted slightly to concerns about volume fluctuations and execution on expansion, compared to a broader focus on payer mix and quality in Q2.
  • Management tone remained confident, with slight increases in detail regarding expansion and operational efficiency.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management cited the unpredictability of net provider taxes as a potential wildcard for future results.
  • Volume fluctuations were discussed, with Coltharp noting timing of capacity additions and holiday timing as factors.
  • Analyst concerns included sustainability of volume growth, labor cost control, and regulatory risks, but management reported no material surprises or negative developments.

Final Takeaway

Encompass Health Corporation reported robust revenue and EBITDA growth in Q3 2025, again raising full-year guidance and significantly increasing its multiyear expansion plans for hospital beds. Management attributed performance to solid demand, strong operational execution, and continued investment in capacity. Bed addition targets and a substantial pipeline reflect confidence in market opportunity, while financial discipline and liquidity remain priorities. The company sees itself well positioned to capitalize on demographic trends and underserved demand in inpatient rehabilitation, with leadership emphasizing steady growth and high barriers to competition.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Markel Group outlines 10% share reduction and 11% premium growth amid insurance restructuring
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Markel Group Inc. (MKL) Q3 2025

Management View

  • CEO Thomas Gayner stated that "every reportable segment made positive contributions to the value of the Markel Group" in the first nine months of 2025, emphasizing the capital-efficient model and significant cash flows supporting share repurchases and liquidity.
  • Gayner highlighted actions to improve the core insurance business: "We've taken many decisive actions over the last few years, including: one, exiting underperforming businesses, most notably reinsurance; two, making key leadership changes, including appointing a new insurance company CEO...; and three, implementing key organizational and structural changes to improve accountability." He noted a combined ratio of 93% in Markel Insurance compared to 97% in the prior period.
  • The company reported returning approximately $1.9 billion to shareholders via repurchases, reducing share count from 13.8 million to 12.6 million since 2020.
  • CFO Brian Costanzo explained, "Consolidated revenues were up 7% for the quarter and 4% year-to-date... Operating income for the quarter was $1 billion versus $1.4 billion in the comparable period last year... Our new metric of adjusted operating income totaled $621 million for the quarter, up $121 million or 24% versus the same period last year."
  • Costanzo noted that insurance contributed $153 million of the adjusted operating income increase for the quarter, driven by underwriting improvements and net investment income.
  • Simon Wilson, CEO of Markel Insurance, said, "Step by step, we're working towards achieving our full potential," detailing portfolio streamlining, cost discipline, and focus on profitable growth through a new go-to-market structure.

Outlook

  • Management reiterated the focus on improving the combined ratio, expense ratio, and return on equity, now tracked as a new metric. Wilson asserted, "We are turning our focus to execution, including developing bottom-up, customer-focused business plans by our new P&L owners for 2026 and beyond."
  • Gayner signaled continued share repurchases: "Our largest single capital allocation choice has been to repurchase shares... The next 10% reduction, I don't think that will take 5 years... that might happen in 3 to 5 years."
  • Costanzo stated, "We expect to bring those [expenses] down over time, we're really focused on the combined ratio and the overall profitability of the business and in our return on equity."

Financial Results

  • Consolidated revenues grew 7% for the quarter. Operating income for the quarter was $1 billion, with net investment gains of $433 million and adjusted operating income at $621 million, a 24% year-over-year increase.
  • Insurance segment adjusted operating income was $428 million for the quarter, up from $276 million last year. The combined ratio stood at just under 93%, a four-point improvement, driven by lower catastrophe activity and reduced losses from CPI.
  • Gross written premiums in insurance rose 11% year-over-year for the quarter. International and Programs and Solutions divisions saw strong growth in underwriting premiums of 25% and 12%, respectively.
  • Operating cash flows for the first nine months reached $2.1 billion. Comprehensive income to shareholders was $793 million for the quarter.
  • Share count was reduced to 12.6 million from 12.8 million at year-end 2024 through $344 million in repurchases this year.

Q&A

  • Andrew Kligerman, TD Cowen, asked about the expense ratio and technology investment. Brian Costanzo responded, "We're kind of right where we thought we would be for this year... As we look to reduce it, and we very much are focused on that as a strategic imperative, we need to do that in areas where we're actually cutting costs out of the business, which are frictional costs."
  • Kligerman inquired about premium growth, with Costanzo detailing that Wholesale and Specialty was down due to product exits, while casualty lines grew "driven by rate." Wilson added, "casualty is a difficult class... we're certainly not putting our foot to the floor... even though the rating is pretty attractive."
  • Andrew Andersen, Jefferies, questioned reserve development. Costanzo replied, "We did have a couple of large claims come in... While we had adverse development there, it's nothing to the range of the things we've been talking about in the past few years."
  • Mark Hughes, Truist, asked about combined ratio opportunities internationally. Wilson stated, "There are plenty of places in the U.S. where you can go after business from a loss ratio perspective... our international business at a small and micro end of the risk area... typically a relatively low loss ratio, but it does go alongside that higher expense ratio."
  • Drew Estes, Banyan, sought clarity on fronting operations, with Costanzo explaining, "The State National business, the traditional program services business, that sits in the Financial Services segment."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts pressed on efficiency, profitability, capital allocation, and competitive dynamics, with a neutral to slightly positive tone, highlighting interest in underlying business drivers and sustainability of improvements.
  • Management maintained a confident and constructive tone during prepared remarks and Q&A, emphasizing discipline, "We are turning our focus to execution," and recurring themes of rational capital allocation and cost management.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, analyst questioning was less focused on reserve actions and more on growth and capital deployment. Management demonstrated increased confidence, as seen in, "We're back," and projected further improvement.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • The current quarter featured improved combined ratio (93% vs. 97%) and a shift to growth in gross written premiums (11% increase vs. prior declines).
  • Management's tone was more optimistic, with greater emphasis on execution and growth, compared to the previous quarter's focus on restructuring and reserve strengthening.
  • Analysts shifted from probing on reserve actions and runoff impacts to questions about premium growth, capital allocation, and segment profitability.
  • Financial disclosures were further enhanced, continuing the trend from the previous quarter.
  • Progress on share repurchases continued, with a notable reduction in share count.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management cited market competition, especially in property and casualty, and the expense ratio as ongoing challenges. Wilson said, "We are focused on the expense ratio. It is in the context of the most important metric that we have is the combined ratio."
  • Costanzo noted headwinds in the industrial segment from softening auto demand and higher costs.
  • Analysts raised concerns about sustainability of premium growth, competitive pressures in fronting, and the potential for expense ratio improvement.

Final Takeaway

Markel Group management underscored that decisive restructuring and disciplined capital allocation are translating into improved insurance profitability and strong cash generation. The company continues to focus on cost management, simplification, and supporting growth in high-performing divisions, while maintaining a track record of conservative reserving and ongoing share repurchases to drive shareholder value.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Xerox targets $300M in Lexmark synergies and 13% revenue growth amid macro headwinds
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Xerox Holdings Corporation (XRX) Q3 2025

Management View

  • CEO Steven Bandrowczak opened by highlighting the integration progress following the Lexmark acquisition, stating, "Their efforts have positioned the combined company for long-term success by harnessing the strengths of both organizations, offerings and sales approaches." He noted the appointment of several Lexmark executives in key roles and the identification of "an additional $50 million of synergy opportunities, some of which we expect will be realized in 2026." Bandrowczak expressed disappointment with Q3 results due to macroeconomic challenges, reporting revenue of $1.96 billion—up approximately 28% due to acquisitions but down 8% pro forma. He added, "Free cash flow was $131 million, an increase of $24 million over the prior year, and adjusted earnings per share of $0.20 decreased $0.05 year-over-year."
  • Bandrowczak cited continued disruption from tariffs and government funding uncertainty, primarily affecting print equipment and supplies, while IT Solutions grew double digits pro forma. He announced new product launches, including three new production printing presses, and detailed the shift to an inside sales model with early evidence of effectiveness: "the 27,000 accounts transitioned into inside sales showing greater than 30% ESR growth year-over-year."
  • President & COO Louie Pastor, newly appointed to the role, emphasized operational consolidation and the adoption of Lexmark’s technology stack, projecting, "the business benefits are irrefutable. The change management is more streamlined and the implementation process is greatly derisked." Pastor also reported an increase in synergy forecast to at least $300 million and total expected savings from Reinvention to over $1 billion.
  • CFO Mirlanda Gecaj stated, "Revenue grew roughly 28% year-over-year, including the benefits of ITsavvy and Lexmark acquisitions. On a pro forma basis, revenue declined about 8% in actual currency." Gecaj highlighted a 3.3% adjusted operating margin and a 28.9% adjusted gross margin, both down year-over-year, and noted, "Adjusted EPS of $0.20 was $0.05 lower than the prior year, primarily due to lower adjusted operating income and higher interest expenses, partially offset by tax benefits."

Outlook

  • Gecaj provided updated 2025 guidance: "We now expect 2025 revenue to grow about 13% year-over-year in constant currency with an adjusted operating margin of roughly 3.5% due to lower sales and a slower-than-expected rollout of price increases targeted at offsetting product cost increases and tariffs." Free cash flow guidance was reduced from $250 million to $150 million, reflecting transaction costs and lower profit.
  • Looking to 2026, Gecaj said, "we see meaningful opportunity for recovery once funding and tariff policies stabilize." Legacy Xerox is expected to decline low to mid-single digits, Lexmark revenue to be flat to down low single digits, and IT Solutions to grow above its market estimated at 7% to 8%. Synergy and savings are targeted at $250 million to $300 million, offset by $60 million in profit headwinds from finance receivables and $100 million from tariffs and product costs.

Financial Results

  • Revenue for Q3 was $1.96 billion. Adjusted operating margin was 3.3% and adjusted gross margin was 28.9%. Free cash flow was $131 million. Adjusted EPS was $0.20, while GAAP loss per share was ($6.01), narrowed from the prior year.
  • Print and Other segment: Equipment sales were $383 million, up 13% due to acquisitions, but down 16% pro forma. Legacy Xerox equipment sales declined 14% year-over-year in constant currency. Total equipment installations for legacy Xerox declined 24%. Lexmark equipment sales declined 30% in actual currency, with installations down 25%.
  • IT Solutions revenue and gross profit increased more than 150% year-over-year with ITsavvy’s inclusion. Pro forma IT Solutions revenue grew just over 12%, with gross billings up 27% and bookings up 11%. Gross margin for IT Solutions was 19.5%, up 320 basis points. Segment profit margin reached 8.1%.
  • Total debt at quarter end was $4.4 billion, up $460 million from Q2, primarily from Lexmark acquisition financing. Gross debt leverage is now 6.1x LTM EBITDA, down 1.5 turns from Q2, with a medium-term target of 3x.

Q&A

  • Ananda Baruah, Loop Capital, questioned the impact of government versus commercial demand on equipment sales. Bandrowczak explained, "We saw some slowdown with our partners... But we also saw any clients that were impacted or could be impacted by either federal or the tariffs was pausing...we expect that business and that volume to come back."
  • Baruah followed up on integration savings. Gecaj responded, "We expect about half of that to flow through in 2026 and the rest in 2027, 2028."
  • Maya Neuman, Morgan Stanley, asked about tariff headwinds. Gecaj stated, "We expect about $35 million net impact from tariffs in 2025, and that is included in our guidance."
  • Asiya Merchant, Citi, inquired on government softness and free cash flow. Bandrowczak stressed the "broad overall impact on spending," with IT prioritizing certain areas and ITsavvy benefiting. Gecaj outlined expectations for $400 million in proceeds from finance receivables reduction and $50 million in one-time costs for synergy savings in 2026.
  • Merchant also asked about market share. Bandrowczak responded, "we don't see losing share. We're holding share."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts’ tone was slightly negative, pressing on the drivers of revenue softness, tariff impacts, and clarity on cost savings and free cash flow. Questions focused on parsing government and commercial headwinds, and whether cost actions would flow through to the bottom line.
  • Management’s tone in prepared remarks was confident regarding integration and synergy realization, but more defensive in Q&A, particularly about the timing of revenue recovery and tariff headwinds. Bandrowczak stated, "we expect that business and that volume to come back," indicating cautious optimism. Gecaj confirmed, "we are taking a step back and looking at case by case as we apply these price increases."
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management’s tone shifted from constructive and forward-looking to more cautious, reflecting greater macro uncertainty and a reduction in outlook. Analyst skepticism increased as revenue and operating income fell short of prior expectations.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance for 2025 revenue growth was reduced to 13% from the prior range of 16–17%. Adjusted operating margin guidance fell to 3.5% from 4.5%, and free cash flow target was lowered to $150 million from $250 million.
  • Management increased the Lexmark synergy goal to $300 million, up from $250 million. The outlook for tariff headwinds worsened, with the impact now expected at the high end of the previous range.
  • Analysts’ questions shifted toward parsing the drivers of the revenue decline, the ability to realize synergy savings, and the durability of market share, compared to earlier focus on integration execution and cross-sell momentum.
  • Management’s confidence in synergy realization increased, but overall sentiment became more reserved due to persistent macro and policy-related uncertainty.

Risks and Concerns

  • Persistent macroeconomic uncertainty and delayed government funding continue to impact equipment sales and revenue growth.
  • Tariff and product cost increases remain a significant headwind, with $35 million expected in 2025 and $100 million in 2026 profit headwinds.
  • Delayed realization of synergy and cost savings due to integration complexities.
  • High gross debt leverage (6.1x LTM EBITDA) despite targeted reduction.
  • Analyst concerns about pace of recovery, the timing of deferred equipment purchases, and the effect of ongoing policy uncertainty on revenue.

Final Takeaway

Management emphasized that, despite near-term macroeconomic and policy headwinds, the integration of Lexmark and ITsavvy has positioned Xerox for long-term value creation, with increased synergy targets and a focus on operational efficiency, debt reduction, and product innovation. The company expects the stabilization of external factors to unlock delayed demand and drive growth, while maintaining a disciplined approach to cost management, capital allocation, and strategic execution.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Amazon's Jassy touts future of AWS, grocery delivery, and AI-integration in retail
data.description:
Amazon (AMZN) shares continued to gain ground in late trading on Thursday with the company’s earnings call highlighting the advancements in its cloud computing segment, new features on its ecommerce site, and growth expectations for its ad business.

Chief executive Andy Jassy kicked off the call with the progress on Amazon Web Services and its meteoric growth potential.

“We are focused on accelerating the capacity [of AWS] and expect to double capacity from a projected 4.8 GW by the end of 2027,” Jassy said.

“Another place where we see a lot of growth is in the number of enterprises who have gotten back to moving from on-premises infrastructure to the cloud, and we continue to earn the lion’s share of those transformations…and I continue to believe that we can grow at a clip like this for a while,” he continued.

In the ecommerce space, Jassy is most excited by the reception to its perishable delivery business and the overwhelming adoption of the service.

“We’re onto something significant [in perishable grocery delivery],” Jassy said, and noted that the explosive growth of this category puts Amazon (AMZN) as the third largest grocery business in the country. Amazon (AMZN) plans to offer same-day perishable delivery in 2,300 cities by the end of this year.

The integration of AI in the retail space presents a significant opportunity for Amazon, Jassy says, noting the popularity of the company’s Rufus shopping assistant which added $10B to in incremental sales.

Ahead of its Q3 results, Amazon (AMZN) announced significant corporate job cuts. When asked if the reductions were driven by AI efficiencies or cost considerations, CEO Andy Jassy said they were primarily motivated by culture.

“When you grow as fast as we did over several years, the number of people, the number of locations, you end up with a lot more people than you had before, and a lot more layers. When that happens, sometimes without realizing it you can weaken the ownership of the people doing the actual work.”      

So, in order to keep Amazon (AMZN) operating like the world’s largest start-up, “it’s important to be lean, it’s important to be flat, and it’s important to be fast,” Jassy said.

Management ended the call with shares more than 13% higher from Thursday's close.

data.title: Asure outlines 2026 revenue target of $158M–$162M with margin expansion as Asure Central launches
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Asure Software (ASUR) Q3 2025

Management View

  • CEO Patrick Goepel highlighted that "our third quarter revenues were very strong, coming in at $36.3 million, 24% increase versus the prior year third quarter." He attributed the growth to broad-based performance across all product lines, including payroll, benefits, recruiting, time and attendance, and payroll tax management.
  • Goepel stated, "Organic growth in the third quarter improved sequentially from the second quarter, and we're forecasting continued improvement in the future."
  • The recent acquisition of Lathem Time was addressed as performing well, with management "continuing to work on achieving revenue and cost synergies going forward, which we believe can be obtained over the next 12 months."
  • Goepel announced the launch of "a new client interface, which we call Asure Central," describing it as "a major enhancement to our client experience" and as a catalyst for accelerating cross-selling rates.
  • CFO John Pence reported, "Third quarter total revenue was $36.3 million, increasing by 24% compared to the prior year period. Recurring revenues for the third quarter grew 11% versus the prior year to $31.8 million."
  • Pence referenced the Lathem acquisition as a key driver for hardware revenue growth and emphasized ongoing improvements in organic growth and attach rates.

Outlook

  • Pence provided guidance for Q4 2025, stating "we are expecting fourth quarter revenues to be in the range of $38 million to $40 million, and adjusted EBITDA for the fourth quarter is expected to be between $10 million and $12 million."
  • Full-year 2025 guidance projects revenue "between $139 million to $141 million, with adjusted EBITDA margins of between 22% and 23%."
  • Initial 2026 guidance forecasts revenue "between $158 million and $162 million, with adjusted EBITDA margins of between 23% to 25%."
  • Goepel commented, "We're well on our way to our medium-term plan of between $180 million to $200 million in revenues, where we believe we can achieve adjusted EBITDA margins of 30% plus."

Financial Results

  • Recurring revenues for Q3 2025 were $31.8 million.
  • Professional services and hardware revenue reached $4.4 million, attributed largely to the Lathem acquisition.
  • Gross profit for Q3 was $23.1 million, while gross margin was 64%. Non-GAAP gross margin was 70%.
  • Net loss stood at ($5.4 million), with EBITDA of $3.9 million and adjusted EBITDA of $8.1 million. Adjusted EBITDA margin was 22%.
  • As of September 30, 2025, cash and cash equivalents totaled $21.5 million with debt at $70.4 million.

Q&A

  • Joshua Reilly, Needham & Company, LLC: Asked for clarification on organic growth and the impact of cross-sell vs. net new units. Goepel replied that "cross-sell results were up 7% quarter-over-quarter, and that's without Asure Central."
  • Jared Levine, TD Cowen: Inquired about sales cycles and pipeline. Goepel responded, "In the segment of the market we play... we're not seeing too much slowdown... Pipeline views look pretty strong."
  • Eric Martinuzzi, Lake Street: Queried on the Lathem revenue contribution and recurring vs. hardware mix. Pence said, "the net impact before the acquisition was roughly $4.7 million or $4.6 million... about $2.7 million or so of that $4.7 million... is recurring."
  • Richard Baldry, ROTH Capital Partners: Asked about Asure Central's impact on legacy stack costs and integration with Lathem. Goepel confirmed "we're already seeing some pretty good cost initiatives around some of our costs" and that Lathem integration is targeted for "first quarter" next year.
  • Gregory Gibas, Northland: Asked about attach rates. Pence replied, "single digits sequentially increasing... about 7% sequentially in terms of the improvement quarter-to-quarter."
  • Alexander Neumann, Stephens: Sought details on Asure Central and its impact on ARPU. Goepel stated, "we do anticipate upticks... we had a 7% improvement in unit volume, and we really didn't have Asure Central yet."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts exhibited a slightly positive tone, with multiple questions focused on growth drivers, integration, and the new platform's potential but without pressing on negative performance issues.
  • Management maintained a confident and optimistic tone during prepared remarks and Q&A, with Goepel stating "we are at an inflection point in the business... we will continue to increase our growth organically while potentially being GAAP profitable in Q4 of 2025 and for the year 2026."
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management sentiment increased in positivity, shifting from "solid" performance to describing the quarter as an "inflection point" and highlighting accelerating growth metrics.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance for 2025 revenue was narrowed but remains in line with the increased range introduced last quarter, now $139 million to $141 million versus $138 million to $142 million previously.
  • Adjusted EBITDA margin guidance is slightly lower, now 22%-23% compared to 22%-24% last quarter.
  • Organic growth improved sequentially, moving from 1% in Q2 to 4% in Q3; excluding ERTC churn, organic growth was 7% vs. 5% previously.
  • Attach rates continue to rise, with management now citing a 7% quarter-over-quarter increase versus 400 basis points year-over-year in Q2.
  • Management's tone is more upbeat, referencing an "inflection point" and projecting greater confidence in achieving GAAP profitability and margin expansion.
  • Analyst questions focused more on the sustainability of growth and integration execution, reflecting growing confidence in the company's trajectory.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management noted ongoing headwinds from float revenue due to Federal Reserve rate cuts, though these are expected to be partially offset by increasing client balances.
  • ERTC-related churn continues to be a factor, though Pence said "there's probably another 1% maybe impact in the fourth quarter, and then we'll never have to talk about it again."
  • Integration of Lathem Time and achieving the modeled revenue and cost synergies remain an execution risk.
  • Gross margin was impacted by a higher mix of lower-margin, nonrecurring revenue from hardware sales.

Final Takeaway

Management underscored that Asure is experiencing an inflection point, marked by accelerating organic growth, rising attach rates, and a successful rollout of Asure Central, which is expected to further enhance cross-sell opportunities. The company is targeting substantial revenue and margin expansion into 2026, with increased confidence in reaching GAAP profitability and leveraging recent acquisitions for broader product integration and efficiency gains. Investors are guided to expect continued positive momentum in both growth and profitability as the business enters its next phase.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Agnico Eagle signals $2.2B net cash position and targets 1.3M–1.5M ounces from pipeline projects as productivity focus intensifies
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Agnico Eagle Mines Limited (AEM) Q3 2025

Management View

  • CEO Ammar Al-Joundi opened the call highlighting, "we're reporting record financial results, driven by, of course, record gold prices, but coupled with strong and consistent operational performance." Al-Joundi emphasized the delivery of 867,000 ounces in gold production for the quarter, achieving 77% of the full-year guidance and selling gold at an average price of $3,476 per ounce, which was noted as a company record. The CEO also drew attention to the company's ability to maintain cost controls, stating, "our Q3 cash costs would have been $933 an ounce, well below the midpoint of our cost guidance range" excluding higher royalties tied to gold prices. Al-Joundi emphasized that Agnico Eagle is "in the strongest financial position in the company's history," and pointed out the ongoing investments into five key pipeline projects and an "exceptional exploration program." The company repaid $400 million in debt, returned $350 million to shareholders, and increased its net cash position to $2.2 billion, also receiving a credit rating upgrade.

  • James Porter, Executive VP of Finance & CFO, stated, "The strong operational performance and cost control paired with higher gold prices to drive record financial results, including record revenue of $3.1 billion, record adjusted earnings of $1.1 billion or $2.16 per share and record adjusted EBITDA of $2.1 billion." Porter added, "We generated $1.2 billion of free cash flow this quarter and added another $400 million through the sale of equity investments."

  • Dominique Girard, Executive VP and COO of Nunavut, Quebec & Europe, highlighted ongoing productivity and technology improvements, noting a 13% year-over-year increase in tonnes mined per day at Kittila and a 4% decrease in euro per tonne cost. He also referenced remote operations technology and the upcoming implementation of an underground fleet management system.

Outlook

  • Management affirmed confidence in achieving the midpoint of the full-year production guidance range of 3.4 million ounces. Porter indicated, "we still expect to be at or near the top end of our cash cost guidance range of $965 per ounce for the full year," and "we also expect to be close to the top end of our all-in sustaining cost guidance range of $1,300 per ounce on a full year basis."

  • The company continues to prioritize shareholder returns, capital discipline, and reinvestment in high-return organic growth projects, reiterating the strategic focus on the five key pipeline projects, which collectively represent about 1.3 million to 1.5 million ounces of potential production.

Financial Results

  • Agnico Eagle reported record revenue of $3.1 billion, record adjusted earnings of $1.1 billion or $2.16 per share, and record adjusted EBITDA of $2.1 billion. Free cash flow for the quarter was $1.2 billion, with a net cash balance rising to $2.2 billion.

  • Gold production for Q3 was approximately 867,000 ounces at total cash costs of $994 per ounce and all-in sustaining costs of $1,373 per ounce. Management noted that higher gold prices resulted in increased royalty expense, with Q3 cash costs about $60 per ounce higher than budgeted.

  • The company returned $350 million to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases and repaid $400 million of debt during the quarter.

Q&A

  • Fahad Tariq, Jefferies: Asked about noncore investments in critical minerals and the strategy for the new subsidiary. CEO Al-Joundi responded that, "we want to remain a gold company," and explained that the new subsidiary provides independence to a small team to explore critical metals opportunities, but the company is not obliged to invest further.

  • Anita Soni, CIBC: Inquired about resource updates at Hope Bay and inflation expectations. Dominique Girard indicated a PEA study is expected in the first half of next year with engineering over 40%. CFO Porter stated, "Going into 2026, I think we're seeing a similar level of inflation in around 6% to 7%, across all of our various cost components."

  • John Tumazos, Very Independent Research: Asked for a breakdown of drilling rigs. Guy Gosselin explained the number of rigs is consistent quarter-over-quarter, with increased productivity allowing for more drilling at lower unit cost.

  • Tanya Jakusconek, Scotiabank: Questioned reserve and resource replacement and the approach to reserve pricing. Gosselin stated, "we are in a good position to fully replace what we mine at Kittila, Macassa and several of our sites will see some partial replacement." Gosselin added that inflation adjustments to reserve pricing are considered on a mine-by-mine basis, but the company intends to keep cut-off grades stable while offsetting inflation.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts' tone was constructive but probing, focusing on the sustainability of cost controls, inflation impacts, and the company's approach to reserve/resource management. Questions on strategic investments and portfolio management indicated close scrutiny of capital allocation.

  • Management maintained a confident and upbeat tone in prepared remarks, frequently using phrases such as "record results," "exceptional job," and "strongest financial position." In Q&A, the tone remained disciplined and occasionally defensive when clarifying capital allocation or noncore investments, as seen in Al-Joundi's response, "we want to remain a gold company."

  • Compared to the previous quarter, both management and analysts sustained a positive outlook, though the current quarter featured more focus on productivity initiatives and inflationary pressures.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • The company again reported record financial performance, with new records in revenue, adjusted earnings, and EBITDA. Net cash position increased from almost $1 billion in Q2 to $2.2 billion in Q3.

  • Management's language around productivity improvement was more pronounced, with specific examples of technological advancements and efficiency gains.

  • Analysts continued to focus on capital allocation and reserve/resource strategies but pressed more on inflation expectations and the sustainability of cost performance.

  • The confidence in achieving guidance, maintaining capital discipline, and delivering on pipeline projects was reiterated, with management's tone remaining highly positive and focused on operational excellence and shareholder returns.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management highlighted inflationary pressures, particularly labor inflation at 6% to 7% across cost components and higher royalty expenses due to elevated gold prices.

  • Analysts raised concerns about cost inflation, reserve/resource pricing adjustments, and the impact of higher gold prices on royalty costs.

  • Management emphasized ongoing cost control initiatives, productivity improvements, and the use of technology to mitigate cost pressures, as well as a disciplined approach to capital allocation and noncore investments.

Final Takeaway

Agnico Eagle Mines Limited delivered record financial results in Q3 2025, backed by strong gold production, robust cost control, and record gold prices. Management reinforced its commitment to operational excellence, productivity improvements, and disciplined capital allocation. The company is well-positioned to achieve its full-year production and cost guidance, advance its key pipeline projects, and continue returning cash to shareholders, while actively managing inflationary risks and maintaining a strong financial position for future growth.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: China to buy 12M metric tons of U.S. soybeans this season, 87M tons through 2028
data.description:
China has agreed to buy 12 million metric tons of U.S. soybeans during the current season through January and 25 million tons/year for the next three years, as part of a larger trade agreement between the twp countries, U.S. Treasury Secretary Bessent said Thursday.

The deal would represent a return to normalcy in trade with the top U.S. soy importer, which averaged purchases of 28.8 million tons over the previous five September-to-August crop seasons.

Bessent also said other countries in Southeast Asia have agreed to buy another 19 million tons of U.S. soybeans, but did not specify a timeframe or the countries involved; Asian importers other than China have imported 8 million-10 million tons/year in recent years.

The Chinese purchase agreements "are not numbers that are unattainable, but they're also not numbers that are really supporting the idea of expansion for our U.S. soybean export program," Zaner Ag Hedge chief market strategist Ted Seifried said, according to Reuters.

Following Bessent's clarification, the most-active January soybean contract (S_1:COM) on the Chicago Board of Trade reversed earlier losses and closed +1.1% at $11.06 1/2 per bushel, its first settlement over the $11 level since July 2024.

But no information was disclosed regarding corn or wheat, which pressured prices: CBOT wheat (W_1:COM) for December delivery ended -1.5% to $5.24 1/2 per bushel, and corn (C_1:COM) for December delivery finished -1% to $4.29 3/4 per bushel.

"Corn and wheat not only were left out of the trade agreement, but also have a negative seasonal tendency beginning in early November," Midwest Market Solutions' Brian Hoops said in a note. "Without news from the trade agreement, positive fundamental information is lacking for corn and even more so for wheat."

ETFs: (SOYB), (WEAT), (CORN), (DBA), (MOO)

data.title: Patrick Industries projects 2026 operating margin uplift of 70–90 bps as content per unit and composites drive growth
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Patrick Industries (PATK) Q3 2025

Management View

  • CEO Andy L. Nemeth opened by highlighting a 6% increase in net sales to $976 million for the quarter, with organic growth contributing more than 4% and offsetting an almost 2% decline in industry shipment levels. Nemeth stated, "Our results reflect both the strength of our diversified business model, solid organic growth as a result of our team's innovation and advanced product efforts and their incredible execution as we continue to navigate dynamic demand levels across our end markets and challenges facing the broader economy."
  • Nemeth emphasized a strong balance sheet with total net liquidity of $779 million, enabling flexibility and continued investment in aftermarket and new product development. He also highlighted ongoing digital transformation: "We are continuing to invest in digital tools, data analytics and AI-powered solutions across our business to drive greater efficiency, accelerate decision-making, reduce costs and unlock new value for our customers."
  • Strategic acquisitions such as LilliPad Marine, Medallion Instrumentation Systems, and Elkhart Composites were noted as strengthening the Patrick platform, along with the unification of composite solutions under the Alpha Composites brand.
  • President Jeffrey Rodino reported RV revenue rose 7% to $426 million. He outlined content per unit (CPU) gains across all Outdoor Enthusiast and Manufactured Housing markets, stating, "Our RV content per unit on a TTM basis was $5,055, an increase of 3% from the same period last year. On a quarterly basis, CPU increased 8% sequentially compared to the second quarter of 2025 and increased 9% year-over-year."
  • Rodino added that Marine revenue increased 11% to $150 million, with content gains and lean dealer inventory positioning the company for future restocking opportunities.
  • CFO Andrew Roeder stated, "Gross margin was 22.6% versus 23.1% in the third quarter of last year. The decline reflected items, including short-term inefficiencies related to the model year changeover. Operating margin was 6.8% compared to the prior year at 8.1%."

Outlook

  • CFO Roeder provided updated industry guidance: "We estimate RV retail unit shipments will be down low single digits in 2025 with estimated full year RV industry wholesale unit shipments between the range of 335,000 to 345,000 units...In Marine, we estimate retail shipments will be down high single digits and estimate wholesale shipments will decline low single digits."
  • For Powersports, Roeder said, "We now estimate that wholesale industry shipments will be down high single digits and our organic content will be up high single digits, offsetting the industry decline."
  • He projected full year 2025 adjusted operating margin of approximately 7% and gave an initial 2026 view: "We expect our operating margin in 2026 to improve meaningfully, an estimated 70 to 90 basis points."

Financial Results

  • Consolidated net sales for the quarter increased 6% to $976 million, driven by revenue gains in Outdoor Enthusiasts and Housing markets.
  • Net income was $35 million or $1.01 per diluted share compared to net income of $41 million in the prior year quarter. Adjusted EBITDA was $112 million compared to $121 million, with an adjusted EBITDA margin of 11.5%, down 170 basis points from the third quarter of 2024.
  • Cash provided by operations for the first 9 months of 2025 was $199 million, and free cash flow for the same period was approximately $134 million.
  • The company returned approximately $13 million to shareholders through quarterly dividends and repurchased 377,600 shares year-to-date through the third quarter for $32 million.

Q&A

  • Scott Stember, ROTH Capital, asked about OEM production ramp-up and aftermarket strategies. President Rodino replied, "We're seeing a little of that...just the pure production numbers would tell us that there is some ramping up..."
  • Stember inquired about aftermarket progress with RecPro. Rodino noted, "We've had several hundred SKUs that have carried over from other Patrick divisions into RecPro this year so far."
  • Stember questioned operating margin expansion. CFO Roeder answered, "A lot of it is going to be sales leverage...content gains, the solutions that we're putting together for customers...automation efforts...a combination of all of those across the platform."
  • Joseph Altobello, Raymond James, followed up on margin pressure. Roeder cited "model change inefficiency" and "short-term investments" as drivers.
  • Noah Zatzkin, KeyBanc, probed the CPU opportunity and composites. Rodino replied, "Our expectation is composites is going to be a big part of that...the total addressable market in that composite area is about $1.5 billion."
  • Multiple analysts raised questions about inventory restocking, margin mix, and the addressable composites market, with management emphasizing lean inventory and a restocking opportunity.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analyst tone was generally neutral to slightly positive, centering on operational execution, margin drivers, and inventory levels. Questions frequently sought clarity on the sustainability of recent gains and the impact of model year transitions.
  • Management maintained a confident and occasionally defensive tone regarding margin pressures, with phrases like "We expect to be able to really leverage our fixed cost structure today" and "we're definitely picking up nickels and dimes along the way as it relates to the automation efforts."
  • Compared to the previous quarter, analyst sentiment was more focused on margin recovery and inventory dynamics, while management's confidence appeared steady but more attuned to justifying short-term gross margin declines.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance for RV and Marine shipments remains largely consistent quarter-over-quarter, though the initial 2026 outlook now projects operating margin improvement of 70 to 90 basis points.
  • Strategic focus has shifted more pointedly toward composite solutions and aftermarket expansion, with the formal launch of a direct-to-consumer strategy.
  • Analysts in both quarters concentrated on margin drivers, inventory cycles, and content per unit growth, with a greater emphasis this quarter on composites and margin mix.
  • Management tone continues to highlight resilience and opportunity, but is now more explicit about margin headwinds from model year changeovers and acquisition-related OpEx.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management cited "short-term inefficiencies related to the model year changeover" and ongoing gross margin pressure.
  • Tariff exposure remains dynamic, with teams "actively working with supply chain partners to minimize the potential impact."
  • Lean inventory levels in RV and Marine channels present both risk and opportunity, with management positioning the company for a potential restock but acknowledging the need for improved consumer confidence and lower interest rates.

Final Takeaway

Patrick Industries management underscored a solid quarter with significant content per unit gains, strong liquidity, and a robust acquisition pipeline. The company is channeling investment into composites, aftermarket expansion, and digital initiatives while navigating model year margin pressure. With lean inventory positioning and a positive outlook for margin expansion in 2026, Patrick Industries aims to capture upside as demand recovers and new product platforms mature.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Escalade signals lower Q4 tariff impact and expands archery leadership through Gold Tip acquisition
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Escalade, Incorporated (ESCA) Q3 2025

Management View

  • Interim President and CEO Patrick Griffin opened the call by addressing the recent leadership transition, stating, “Effective October 29, I was appointed Interim President and CEO by the Board and replaced Armin Boehm, who departed the company on that same date…this transition does not reflect any disruption to our strategic direction or our operations.” Griffin emphasized the company’s commitment to its long-term vision and operational continuity.
  • Griffin reported that Escalade experienced improved results in the quarter, attributing this to “solid demand across most of our portfolio of leading brands as well as cost discipline and operational efficiency.” He highlighted that margin improvement was driven by lower manufacturing and logistics costs, as well as benefits from ongoing footprint rationalization and tariff mitigation initiatives.
  • The launch of over 30 new products in the 2026 archery assortment across Bear, Trophy Ridge, and Cajun brands was noted, with early consumer response described as positive. Griffin also announced the acquisition of Gold Tip, stating, “This acquisition aligns closely with our long-term strategic and financial criteria and will allow us to achieve greater scale and unlock additional synergies. Gold Tip’s 20-year heritage in carbon arrows, along with Bee Stinger’s premium stabilizers, enhances our category leadership and broadens our product offering.”
  • The company implemented targeted price increases in July, based on “careful analysis of price elasticity and market dynamics,” and anticipates continued recalibration as needed.
  • CFO Stephen Wawrin stated, “For the 3 months ended September 30, 2025, Escalade reported net income of $5.6 million or $0.40 per diluted share on net sales of $67.8 million.” Wawrin also cited a gross margin of 28.1% and detailed a decrease in selling, general and administrative expenses by $0.5 million year-over-year to $11.2 million.

Outlook

  • Griffin indicated, “Looking ahead to the fourth quarter, we anticipate consumer spending to remain cautious, consistent with broader retail trends, which are likely to result in softer holiday sales compared to recent years.” He also noted a shift in consumer spending patterns, with strong demand for premium products and softening demand for lower-priced products.
  • Management expects tariff-related cost impact to be lower in the fourth quarter relative to the third quarter, following recent negotiations.
  • The company remains focused on “investing in product innovation and brand development to strengthen our market leadership and to enhance the consumer experience.”

Financial Results

  • Escalade reported net income of $5.6 million or $0.40 per diluted share, on net sales of $67.8 million for Q3 2025.
  • Gross margin for the quarter was 28.1%, up from 24.8% in the prior year period, attributed to lower operational costs and benefits from facility consolidation, partially offset by $4.3 million in tariff-related costs.
  • Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization were $8.6 million, reflecting a decrease primarily due to the absence of a one-time $3.9 million gain from the prior year.
  • Cash used from operations was $1 million, compared to cash provided by operations of $10.5 million in the prior year, due to increased working capital usage and inventory investments ahead of the holiday season.
  • As of September 30, 2025, total cash and equivalents were $3.5 million, with $20.2 million in total debt outstanding and net leverage at 0.7x.

Q&A

  • Rommel Dionisio, Aegis Capital: Asked about market share gains and category performance beyond archery. Griffin responded, “We've had pretty good success in other categories. Just an example, our safety category. We're taking market share there…our games have done well as well.”
  • Dionisio followed up on the pickleball category. Griffin replied, “Pickleball, we've been in pickleball a long time. It's a growing overall market…we're continuing to maintain the market share that we have at retail…we think long term, it's going to be a sport that's going to be around for a long time.”
  • Dionisio inquired about tariff impacts for Q4. Griffin answered, “As you know, that's a dynamic situation right now…directionally, we're expecting the impact to be lower in the fourth quarter relative to the third quarter.”
  • David Cohen, Minerva Advisors: Asked about the CEO search timeline and capital allocation priorities. Griffin explained, “The Board will gather and look for the permanent CEO…that's aligned with our culture as a company that has a growth mindset.” On capital allocation, Griffin said, “We continue to look for acquisitions…continuing to pay a dividend…and then we'll look for share buybacks opportunistically as well.”

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts were inquisitive, focusing on details of category performance, tariff impacts, and capital allocation. The tone was neutral, with some probing for granularity and future expectations.
  • Management maintained a confident and measured tone during prepared remarks, with Griffin stating, “the Board and executive leadership team are confident in our path forward.” During Q&A, Griffin provided direct responses but acknowledged market uncertainties, showing a slightly cautious tone when discussing tariffs and consumer sentiment.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management’s tone remained confident in execution and strategy, but with increased attention on near-term headwinds and operational adjustments. Analyst questions remained focused on performance drivers and risk mitigation.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • The current quarter introduced a significant leadership change with the appointment of an interim CEO, contrasted with stable leadership in the prior quarter.
  • Margin improvement was more pronounced this quarter, with gross margin rising to 28.1% from 24.7% last quarter. Tariff-related costs increased this quarter to $4.3 million from $1.6 million in Q2, but management expects these to be lower in Q4.
  • Inventory investments were higher this quarter to prepare for the holiday season, resulting in negative operating cash flow, compared to positive cash flow in the previous quarter.
  • Strategic focus shifted toward integrating the Gold Tip acquisition and expanding product innovation, while maintaining operational discipline and cost controls.
  • Analysts’ focus shifted slightly from product cadence and margin mix last quarter to market share gains, category performance, and capital allocation this quarter.
  • Both management and analysts maintained a neutral to slightly positive sentiment, with continued attention to risks and execution.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management highlighted ongoing consumer uncertainty and elevated price sensitivity, particularly among middle and lower-income consumers, leading to delays or reductions in discretionary purchases.
  • Tariff-related costs remain a risk, though management expects the impact to moderate in Q4. Proactive supply chain and inventory management strategies are being used to mitigate these risks.
  • Analyst questions reflected concerns about tariff impacts, leadership stability, and capital allocation priorities amid evolving market conditions.

Final Takeaway

Escalade’s third quarter featured a pivotal leadership transition and a focus on operational efficiency, margin improvement, and category expansion, notably in archery through the Gold Tip acquisition. Despite heightened tariff-related costs and ongoing consumer uncertainty, management remains confident in its long-term strategy, active product innovation, and disciplined capital allocation to navigate near-term headwinds and drive shareholder value.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript
